text: Suppose I have an abstract type `AbsT` and concrete types `T1 <: AbsT`, `T2 <: AbsT` etc. What’s the best way to define a total order on the `T_i`?

elements.text: Suppose I have an abstract type
etc. What’s the best way to define a total order on the

text:
```# I have used this
julia> abstract type AbsT{N} end

julia> struct T1 <: AbsT{1}
         value::Int
       end

julia> struct T2 <: AbsT{2}
         value::Int
       end

julia> struct T3 <: AbsT{3}
         value::Int
       end

julia> t1 = T1(3); t2 = T2(2); t3 = T3(1);

julia> Base.isless(x::AbsT{N1}, y::AbsT{N2}) where {N1,N2} = isless(N1,N2)

julia> isless(t1,t2)
true

julia> isless(t3,t1)
false```

elements.text:
# I have used this
julia> abstract type AbsT{N} end

julia> struct T1 <: AbsT{1}
         value::Int
       end

julia> struct T2 <: AbsT{2}
         value::Int
       end

julia> struct T3 <: AbsT{3}
         value::Int
       end

julia> t1 = T1(3); t2 = T2(2); t3 = T3(1);

julia> Base.isless(x::AbsT{N1}, y::AbsT{N2}) where {N1,N2} = isless(N1,N2)

julia> isless(t1,t2)
true

julia> isless(t3,t1)
false

text: I think something like that should work, thanks!

elements.text: I think something like that should work, thanks!

text: If throughput matters,  the struct types also use`N` type parameter.
